about.paragraph1: This decision aid will help you explore the different treatment options available for kidney failure. You can learn about each treatment at your own pace, think about what matters most to you, and create a summary to share with your doctor or nurse.
about.paragraph2: You will answer a few simple questions about your situation, then explore treatments that may be suitable for you. Your information stays private and is not saved after you close the browser.
about.paragraph3: This tool does not replace medical advice from your healthcare team. It is designed to help you feel more informed and confident when discussing your options. Your kidney team are the experts in your care and will help you make the right decision for you.

privacy.title: Your Privacy & Information
privacy.subtitle: Before you begin, we want you to understand how this tool handles your information.

privacy.title: How We Protect Your Information
privacy.content: Your responses are processed securely and are not stored permanently. This tool does not collect personal health information that can identify you. Your session data is automatically deleted when you close this tool.
privacy.p1: This tool uses session-only storage. Any information you enter, including your answers to questions and treatment preferences, is only kept while you are using the tool.
privacy.p2: When you close your browser or after 15 minutes of inactivity, all your information is automatically deleted. We do not save anything about you.
privacy.p3: We collect anonymous information about how people use this tool to help us improve it. This cannot identify you personally.

ai.title: How This Tool Works
ai.content: This decision aid uses technology to provide personalised information based on your responses. The information provided is drawn from NHS clinical guidelines and evidence-based research. This tool supports but does not replace discussions with your kidney care team.
ai.p1: This tool includes an AI assistant that can answer general questions about kidney treatments. The AI provides information only - it cannot give you medical advice specific to your situation.
ai.p2: The AI may sometimes make mistakes or provide incomplete information. Always discuss important decisions with your kidney team who know your full medical history.
ai.p3: This tool does not replace advice from your healthcare team. It is designed to help you feel more informed when discussing your options with your doctors and nurses.

medical.title: Important Medical Information
medical.content: This tool provides general information about kidney treatment options. It is not a substitute for professional medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment. Always consult with your kidney specialist or healthcare team before making any decisions about your treatment. If you have urgent health concerns, please contact your GP or call NHS 111.

pii.title: Please Do Not Share Personal Details
pii.intro: To protect your privacy, please do not enter any personal information that could identify you when using this tool, especially in the chat feature.
pii.outro: You can still tell us about your situation in general terms - for example, your living situation or what matters most to you - without sharing identifying details.

treatments.title: Understanding Your Treatment Options
treatments.subtitle: There are different ways to treat kidney failure. Each has benefits and considerations.

conservative.comfort: Focus on comfort and quality of life

transplant.title: Kidney Transplant
transplant.shortDescription: Receiving a healthy kidney from a donor
transplant.description: A kidney transplant involves receiving a healthy kidney from either a living donor (such as a family member or friend) or a deceased donor. A successful transplant can provide the best quality of life and longest survival for many people with kidney failure.
benefits: Often provides the best quality of life
Better energy levels for most people
considerations: Need to take immunosuppressant medications for life
May need to wait for a suitable kidney

hemodialysis.title: Haemodialysis
hemodialysis.description: Haemodialysis uses a machine to filter your blood outside your body. This is usually done at a dialysis unit in hospital or a community centre, typically three times a week for about four hours each session. Some people do haemodialysis at home.
benefits: Effective at removing waste and excess fluid
Home haemodialysis option available for some
considerations: Requires regular hospital or centre visits

peritonealDialysis.title: Peritoneal Dialysis
peritonealDialysis.shortDescription: Filtering blood inside the body using the abdomen lining
peritonealDialysis.description: Peritoneal dialysis uses the lining of your abdomen (peritoneum) as a natural filter. A special fluid is put into your abdomen through a small tube, absorbs waste products, and is then drained out. This can be done at home, either during the day or overnight while you sleep.
benefits: Gentler on the body, fewer ups and downs
considerations: Need a permanent tube in your abdomen
Risk of infection if technique is not maintained

conservative.title: Conservative Management
conservative.description: Conservative management focuses on maintaining quality of life and managing symptoms without dialysis or transplant. This approach may be right for some people, particularly those who are elderly, frail, or have other serious health conditions. It involves careful symptom management, medications, and support from the kidney care team.
benefits: No dialysis sessions or surgery needed
Focus on quality of life and comfort
May be appropriate for some elderly or frail patients
Maintain usual routine as much as possible
considerations: Kidney function will continue to decline
Important to have honest conversations about expectations

modelViewer.title: 3D Kidney Model Viewer
modelViewer.interactiveDescription: Explore an interactive 3D model of human kidneys. Use your mouse or touch to rotate and zoom.
modelViewer.kidneyInfo: Your kidneys are bean-shaped organs about the size of your fist. They filter about 200 litres of blood daily, removing waste and extra fluid.
modelViewer.functionInfo: Kidneys regulate blood pressure, produce hormones, balance body fluids, and filter waste products into urine.
modelViewer.failureInfo: When kidneys lose function, treatments like dialysis or transplant can help do the work your kidneys can no longer do.
modelViewer.continueJourney: Continue your journey by exploring treatment options

kidney.label: Kidney
kidney.description: The main filtering organ that removes waste from your blood and produces urine.

renalArtery.label: Renal Artery
renalArtery.description: Carries blood from the heart to the kidney for filtering.

renalVein.label: Renal Vein
renalVein.description: Carries filtered blood from the kidney back to the heart.

ureter.label: Ureter
ureter.description: The tube that carries urine from the kidney to the bladder.

adrenalGland.label: Adrenal Gland
adrenalGland.description: A small gland on top of the kidney that produces important hormones.

travel.title: What if I want to travel?
travel.description: Explore how each treatment affects your ability to travel for holidays or visits
travel.transplant: After recovery, you can travel freely. Take medications with you and know where to seek care if needed.
travel.transplantTip1: Carry a letter from your transplant team
travel.transplantTip2: Research medical facilities at your destination
travel.transplantTip3: Pack extra medication in hand luggage
travel.hemodialysis: Travel requires advance planning to arrange dialysis at your destination. Holiday dialysis units exist but availability varies.
travel.hemodialysisTip2: Your dialysis team can help with arrangements
travel.hemodialysisTip3: UK travel is easier than international
travel.peritoneal: More freedom to travel. Supplies can be delivered to your destination or you can take them with you.
travel.peritonealTip2: Airlines usually allow extra luggage for supplies
travel.peritonealTip3: Need a clean space for exchanges
travel.conservative: No dialysis restrictions, but travel depends on how you feel. Short trips may be easier to manage.
travel.conservativeTip1: Discuss travel plans with your care team
travel.conservativeTip3: Plan for rest periods during trips

work.title: What if I want to work full-time?
work.description: See how different treatments fit with maintaining employment
work.transplant: After 2-3 months recovery, most people can return to full-time work with near-normal energy levels.
work.transplantTip1: Plan a phased return to work
work.transplantTip2: You may need time off for clinic appointments
work.hemodialysis: Possible but challenging. Sessions take 4-5 hours three times weekly, plus recovery time. Evening/early shifts may help.
work.hemodialysisTip2: Evening or early morning dialysis slots
work.peritoneal: APD overnight means days are free for work. CAPD requires breaks for exchanges but many continue working.
work.peritonealTip1: APD is ideal for full-time workers
work.peritonealTip2: You can do CAPD exchanges at work
work.peritonealTip3: Energy levels often better than HD
work.conservative: Depends on symptoms and energy. Many continue part-time or reduced hours. Focus is on quality of life.

liveAlone.title: What if I live alone?
liveAlone.description: Understand which treatments work well for people living independently
liveAlone.transplant: You will need support during recovery (2-4 weeks), but afterwards can live independently.
liveAlone.transplantTip1: Arrange help for first few weeks post-surgery
liveAlone.hemodialysis: Treatment is done at a centre with professional staff. No home setup required. Regular contact with healthcare team.
liveAlone.peritoneal: Many people do PD alone successfully. Training prepares you well. 24/7 phone support available.
liveAlone.peritonealTip2: Regular home visits from PD nurses
liveAlone.conservative: Initially manageable alone. As symptoms progress, you may need increasing support. Community services can help.
liveAlone.conservativeTip3: Plan ahead for future care needs

family.title: What if I have young children?
family.description: Consider how treatments affect caring for children and family time
family.transplant: After recovery, you can be fully involved in family life. Best quality of life for active parenting.
family.transplantTip2: Can return to normal parenting activities
family.hemodialysis: Regular time away from home for treatment. Tiredness after sessions may affect family activities. Childcare needed during sessions.
family.hemodialysisTip3: Plan family time on non-dialysis days
family.peritoneal: Home-based treatment means more time with family. APD overnight leaves days free for childcare.
family.peritonealTip2: Days are free for school runs
family.conservative: No treatment schedule, but energy levels vary. Focus on quality time with family.
family.conservativeTip2: Accept help with childcare when needed
